Sentences: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and on our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.

Sentences: Household spending on goods has risen robustly.

Sentences: Spending on services has also picked up, including at restaurants and bars.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: More generally, the sectors of the economy most adversely affected by the pandemic remain weak but have shown improvement.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While the recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected, it remains uneven and far from complete.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The path of the economy continues to depend significantly on the course of the virus and the measures undertaken to control its spread.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Since March, progress on vaccinations has limited the number of new cases, hospitalizations, and deaths.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While the level of new cases remains concerning, especially as it reflects the spread of more infectious strains of the virus, continued vaccinations should allow for a return to more normal economic conditions later this year.

Sentences: In the as soon as possible.

Sentences: As with overall economic activity, conditions in the labor market have continued to improve.

Sentences: As we say in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we view maximum employment as a broad-based and inclusive goal.

Sentences: Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As the Committee reiterated in today’s policy statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

Sentences: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

Sentences: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

Sentences: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With inflation having run persistently below 2 percent for some time, the Committee seeks inflation moderately above inflation for two times—above 2 percent for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, with a, a little bit of context, we’re, we’re making our way through an unprecedented series of events, really, in which a synchronized global shutdown is now giving way to widespread reopening of economies in many places around the world.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the United States, fiscal and monetary policy continue to provide strong support:  Vaccinations are now widespread, and the economy is beginning to move ahead with real momentum.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: During this time of reopening, we are likely to see some upward pressure on prices, and I’ll discuss why.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But those pressures are likely to be temporary as they are associated with the reopening process.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In an episode of one-time price increases as the economy reopens is not the same thing as, and is not likely to lead to, persistently higher year-over-year inflation into the future—inflation at levels that are not consistent with our goal of 2 percent inflation over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Indeed, it is the Fed’s job to make sure that that does not happen.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If, if, contrary to expectations, inflation were to move persistently and materially above 2 percent in a manner that threatened to move longer-term inflation expectations materially above 2 percent, we would use our tools to bring a principal difference from—we’re all very familiar at the Fed with the history of the 1960s and ’70s, of course.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we know that our job is to achieve 2 percent inflation over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re committed to that, and we will use our tools to do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s a very different situation than you had back in the 1960s—or many, many differences, actually.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So let me talk quickly about the two reasons—two, or you could say three, but really two main reasons why we think inflation will move up in the near term.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The first is the base effects.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Twelve-month measures of inflation are likely to move well above 2 percent over the next few months as the very low inflation readings recorded in March and April of last year drop out of the calculation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That process has already started to show up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You saw it in the March CPI reading, and you’ll see it later this week in the PCE price data.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These base effects will contribute about 1 percentage point to headline inflation and about 0.7 percentage point to core inflation in April and May.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, significant increases, and they’ll disappear over the following months.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And they’ll be transitory.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They carry no implication for the rate of inflation in later periods.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s base effects.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The other big one I would talk about is bottlenecks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So this is what we’re seeing in supply chains in various industries, and we’re, we’re in close touch with all of these industries.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, the Fed has a network of contacts that is unequaled in businesses and in nonprofits for that matter, too.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So what do we mean by a bottleneck?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: A bottleneck really is a temporary blockage or restriction in the supply chain for, for a particular good or goods, something that slows down the process of producing goods and delivering them to the market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think of bottlenecks as things that, in their nature, will be resolved as workers and businesses adapt, and we think of them as not calling for a change in monetary policy since they’re temporary and It’s much harder to predict with confidence the amount of time it will take to resolve the bottlenecks, or for that matter, the temporary effects that they will have on prices in the meantime.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, you know, I’ll just sum up and say, we understand our job.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will do our job.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we are, we are focused—as you’ve seen, for many years, we’ve been focused on inflation deviating below 2 percent, and we used our tools aggressively to keep it back up at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.
